p: The aqueous extract of the plant is reported to possess the properties of an antidote. It is believed that Romans used to consume the plant extract before or during meal to protect themselves from getting poisoned. Bathing in warm water dosed with T. vulgaris L. could stop the effects of poison, making it a favourite herb for the emperors [ 8]. These examples indicate the effectiveness of T. vulgaris L. as a natural antidote. In support of this, the present-day studies show presence of compounds like thymol and carvacrol, which can serve as a profound antidote [ 31, 32].
